stem: The nurse is caring for a client with type 1 diabetes mellitus who requires insulin. Based on the provided information, match each insulin type to its expected onset, peak, and duration.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
10/26/2026 07:00 - Client reports feeling well this morning. Ate a full breakfast at 06:30. Blood glucose check due before lunch. - Nurse Kim

10/26/2026 11:00 - Pre-lunch blood glucose 250 mg/dL. Client reports no symptoms of hypo- or hyperglycemia. Insulin ordered per sliding scale. - Nurse Kim

10/26/2026 11:15 - 6 units of insulin lispro administered subcutaneously per sliding scale order. Client tolerated injection well. Educated on signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia. Encourage client to report any unusual symptoms. - Nurse Kim

10/26/2026 16:00 - Client ate lunch well and reports feeling fine. Blood glucose trending down. Will check pre-dinner blood glucose at 17:00. - Nurse Kim

10/26/2026 17:00 - Pre-dinner blood glucose 140 mg/dL. Client denies any complaints. Continue to monitor. - Nurse Kim

10/26/2026 21:00 - Pre-bedtime blood glucose 110 mg/dL. Client reports feeling well. Administered 12 units of insulin glargine subcutaneously. - Nurse Kim

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
10/26/2026 07:00
General: Alert and oriented x3, well-nourished, no acute distress.
Skin: Warm, dry, and intact. No lesions or edema.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, normoactive bowel sounds.
Neurological: Gross motor and sensory intact.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
Diabetes Management:
- Monitor blood glucose before meals and at bedtime.
- Administer insulin as prescribed per sliding scale.
- Educate client on insulin administration technique.
- Educate client on signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.
- Encourage client to report any unusual symptoms.
- Dietician consult for diabetic meal planning.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Insulin lispro: 6 units SQ at 11:15 on 10/26/2026
Insulin glargine: 12 units SQ at 21:00 on 10/26/2026

columns.text: Onset: 5-15 min; Peak: 1-2 hr; Duration: 3-5 hr
Onset: 30 min; Peak: 2-4 hr; Duration: 5-8 hr
Onset: 1-2 hr; Peak: 4-12 hr; Duration: 12-18 hr
Onset: 1-2 hr; Peak: None; Duration: 24 hr

rationale.correct:
The correct matches are:
- Insulin Lispro: Onset 5-15 min; Peak 1-2 hr; Duration 3-5 hr.
- Regular Insulin: Onset 30 min; Peak 2-4 hr; Duration 5-8 hr.
- NPH Insulin: Onset 1-2 hr; Peak 4-12 hr; Duration 12-18 hr.
- Insulin Glargine: Onset 1-2 hr; Peak None; Duration 24 hr.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect selections indicate a misunderstanding of the onset, peak, and duration of different types of insulin. This can lead to inappropriate insulin administration and potential complications such as hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.

answerBreakdown.rationale: Insulin lispro is a rapid-acting insulin analog with an onset of 5-15 minutes, a peak of 1-2 hours, and a duration of 3-5 hours. It is often used for bolus injections before meals to cover carbohydrate intake.
Regular insulin is a short-acting insulin with an onset of 30 minutes, a peak of 2-4 hours, and a duration of 5-8 hours. It is typically administered 30 minutes before meals.

NPH insulin is an intermediate-acting insulin with an onset of 1-2 hours, a peak of 4-12 hours, and a duration of 12-18 hours. It is often used as a basal insulin to provide coverage between meals and overnight.

Insulin glargine is a long-acting insulin analog with an onset of 1-2 hours, no pronounced peak, and a duration of 24 hours. It provides a consistent level of insulin coverage over 24 hours and is used as a basal insulin.

clinicalPearls: Understanding the onset, peak, and duration of different insulin types is crucial for preventing hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.
Rapid-acting insulins are used to cover mealtime carbohydrate intake, while long-acting insulins provide basal coverage.
Factors such as injection site, individual metabolism, and activity level can influence insulin absorption and action.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing the peak times of rapid-acting and short-acting insulins is a common mistake.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the onset time to differentiate between rapid-acting and short-acting insulins. Rapid-acting insulins have a very quick onset (5-15 minutes), while short-acting insulins take about 30 minutes to start working.

mnemonic.title: RRapid acting insulin
mnemonic.expansion: Lispro (Humalog) and Aspart (Novolog) act RAPIDLY at mealtime.
